title: R41107
content: Negotiating parties of the proposed Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) have until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. The ACTA would enter into force after the sixth instrument of ratification is deposited. Mexico signed the ACTA on July 11, 2012, requiring ratification in the Mexican Congress. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. On July 4, 2012, the European Parliament voted against the ACTA, preventing the EU and its member states from joining. Several EU countries suspended or did not initiate domestic adoption of the ACTA in early 2012. The European Commission put the ratification process on hold and sent the agreement to the European Court of Justice for review. On January 25, 2012, the European Union and 22 member states signed the ACTA, with five countries not signing due to procedural issues. The ACTA was signed by several countries, including Australia, Canada, Japan, Korea, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, and the United States. The European Union, Mexico, and Switzerland expressed their support and intention to sign the agreement. The final version of the agreement text was released in May 2011 after nearly three years of negotiations. The Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) was finalized in October 2010 after nearly three years of negotiations. It aims to combat intellectual property rights infringement and was negotiated by several countries including the United States, Australia, Canada, the European Union, Japan, South Korea, Mexico, Morocco, New Zealand, Singapore, and Switzerland. The agreement focuses on enforcing trademarks and copyrights, addressing emerging IPR issues not adequately covered in the WTO TRIPS Agreement. The Anti-Counterfeiting Trade Agreement (ACTA) was finalized in October 2010 after nearly three years of negotiations. It focuses on enforcing trademarks and copyrights, addressing IPR infringement in the digital environment. The agreement establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement, including civil enforcement, border measures, and criminal enforcement for trademark counterfeiting and copyright piracy on a commercial scale. It also promotes international cooperation and best practices. Countries had until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. The ACTA negotiation concluded in October 2010, with countries having until May 1, 2013, to sign the agreement. All negotiating parties, except Mexico and Switzerland, have signed the agreement. The idea of negotiating the ACTA was conceived in 2006 by the United States and Japan to combat counterfeiting and piracy. The ACTA negotiation began in 2006 between the United States and Japan to combat counterfeiting and piracy. By 2008, more countries joined the talks, and negotiations continued until October 2010 when most issues were resolved. The ACTA negotiation began in 2006 between the United States and Japan to combat counterfeiting and piracy. By 2008, more countries joined the talks, and negotiations continued until October 2010 when most issues were resolved. The final round was held in Japan in October 2010, during which ACTA participants resolved nearly all substantive issues and produced a largely finalized text of the proposed agreement. On October 1, 2011, several countries signed the ACTA, with others confirming their support and preparations to sign as soon as possible. On January 25, 2012, the European Union and 22 member states signed the ACTA, followed by Mexico on July 11, 2012. The signatories aim to ratify the agreement promptly for it to take effect after the sixth instrument of approval is deposited. Currently, countries are going through their domestic approval processes for the ACTA. No country has deposited an instrument of approval for the ACTA yet. The USTR negotiated the ACTA as an executive agreement, not requiring congressional approval unless it necessitates changes to U.S. law. The European Commission negotiated on behalf of EU member states, where the European Parliament and all 27 member states must sign and ratify the ACTA for it to enter into force. The European Commission negotiated the ACTA for EU member states. The European Parliament voted against the ACTA on July 4, 2012. Several EU member states suspended or did not initiate domestic adoption of the ACTA. The European Commission placed the ACTA ratification process on hold and submitted it to the European Court of Justice for compatibility with EU law. The European Commission placed the ACTA ratification process on hold and submitted it to the European Court of Justice to determine its compatibility with EU law. Some countries may need to pass new laws to implement the enforcement standards of the ACTA, including granting customs officials ex-officio authority and providing legal remedies for circumventing technological protection measures. The ACTA involves investigations into trademark infringement and copyright piracy, as well as legal remedies for circumventing TPM. The digital enforcement standards of the ACTA are based on the WIPO Internet treaties. Canada incorporated these treaties into domestic law with the passage of copyright bill C-11 in 2012. The countries involved in the ACTA negotiations are economically advanced and value IPR-based industries. These countries make up roughly half of total world merchandise exports. The ACTA negotiation involves economically advanced countries valuing IPR-based industries. Participants have acceded to WTO TRIPS Agreement and implemented WIPO Internet treaties. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement and international cooperation. Key provisions include discussions on the agreement's nature, scope, and relationship to existing agreements. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement through increased international cooperation and enhanced enforcement measures. Key provisions include discussions on the agreement's nature, scope, relationship to existing agreements, privacy, disclosure of information, and definitions of terms. It allows flexibility for each Party to implement more extensive IPR enforcement, determine the appropriate method of implementation, and states that TRIPS Agreement principles apply to the ACTA. The ACTA establishes a legal framework for IPR enforcement through international cooperation and enhanced measures. It includes provisions on enforcement obligations, civil and criminal enforcement, border measures, and enforcement in the digital environment. The agreement requires effective enforcement actions that provide expeditious remedies, avoid trade barriers, and ensure fair treatment for participants. The ACTA commits Parties to effective IPR enforcement with expeditious remedies, fair treatment, and proportionate penalties. It mandates civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions and damages for right holders. The ACTA mandates civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, recovery of costs, and provisional measures to prevent infringement. Parties may exclude patents and protection of undisclosed information from this section. The ACTA mandates civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, recovery of costs, and provisional measures to prevent infringement. Parties may exclude patents and protection of undisclosed information from this section. The border measures section concerns effective border enforcement of IPR without discrimination among different forms of IPR and barriers to legitimate trade. Each Party shall adopt procedures for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods. The ACTA mandates civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, recovery of costs, and provisional measures to prevent infringement. Parties may exclude patents and protection of undisclosed information from this section. The border measures section concerns effective border enforcement of IPR without discrimination among different forms of IPR and barriers to legitimate trade. Each Party shall adopt procedures for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods. Goods and right holders may request customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods; procedures for in-transit goods or goods under customs control may be adopted or maintained; competent authorities may determine IPR infringement in a reasonable period; authority to order destruction of infringing goods and impose penalties shall be provided; competent authorities may provide right holders with information on specific shipments to detect infringing goods. Criminal enforcement is also required. The ACTA mandates civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, recovery of costs, and provisional measures to prevent infringement. Parties may exclude patents and protection of undisclosed information from this section. Each Party shall adopt procedures for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods. Goods and right holders may request customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods; procedures for in-transit goods or goods under customs control may be adopted or maintained; competent authorities may determine IPR infringement in a reasonable period; authority to order destruction of infringing goods and impose penalties shall be provided; competent authorities may provide right holders with information on specific shipments to detect infringing goods. Criminal enforcement is also required, including penalties, imprisonment, and seizure of counterfeit goods. The ACTA mandates civil judicial procedures for IPR enforcement, including injunctions, damages, recovery of costs, and provisional measures to prevent infringement. Parties may exclude patents and protection of undisclosed information from this section. The border measures section concerns effective border enforcement of IPR without discrimination among different forms of IPR and barriers to legitimate trade. Each Party shall adopt procedures for customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods. Goods and right holders may request customs authorities to suspend the release of suspect goods; procedures for in-transit goods or goods under customs control may be adopted or maintained; competent authorities may determine IPR infringement in a reasonable period; authority to order destruction of infringing goods and impose penalties shall be provided; competent authorities may provide right holders with information on specific shipments to detect infringing goods. Criminal enforcement is also required, including penalties, imprisonment, and seizure of counterfeit goods. The digital enforcement section discusses obligations for enforcement of copyrights and related rights over digital networks. The digital enforcement section of the ACTA mandates effective enforcement procedures against IPR infringement in the digital environment, including copyright infringement over digital networks. Parties must ensure that enforcement actions do not create barriers to legitimate activity and uphold principles of freedom of expression, fair process, and privacy. Authorities may be granted the power to order online service providers to take action in accordance with their laws and regulations. The curr_chunk focuses on the enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) in the digital environment. It states that a Party may authorize its competent authority to order online service providers to disclose identifying information of subscribers involved in infringement. It also emphasizes the need for legal protection against circumvention of technological measures and protection of electronic rights management information. Additionally, limitations and exceptions may be adopted in implementing these remedies. The enforcement practices chapter addresses the methods used by Parties to enforce IPR laws. The curr_chunk discusses the enforcement of intellectual property rights (IPR) and the methods used by Parties to apply IPR enforcement laws. It emphasizes the development of enforcement expertise, collection of statistical data on IPR infringement, and consultation with relevant stakeholders to manage infringement risks at the border. Additionally, it highlights the sharing of information among competent authorities to better target shipments. The curr_chunk emphasizes the importance of international cooperation among Parties to address challenges in cross-border trade of counterfeit and pirated products. It highlights promoting cooperation among competent authorities responsible for IPR enforcement and promoting public awareness of the negative effects of IPR infringement. Additionally, it mentions considering environmental factors in the destruction of infringing goods. The chapter discusses cooperation among Parties to address challenges in cross-border trade of counterfeit and pirated products. It includes promoting cooperation among competent authorities, exchanging information, providing capacity building, and avoiding duplication in international cooperation activities. An ACTA Committee is established to review implementation, proposed amendments, and terms of accession. The institutional arrangement chapter establishes an ACTA Committee to review the implementation and operation of the agreement, proposed amendments, and terms of accession. The agreement shall remain open for signature by participants and other WTO Members until May 1, 2013, entering into force 30 days after the sixth instrument of ratification. The United States conducted the ACTA negotiation through the USTR. After May 1, 2013, WTO Members can apply to join the agreement. The USTR, under the Office of the President, leads U.S. trade agreement negotiations. The process involves various government departments, advisory groups, congressional committees, and stakeholder groups. The ACTA negotiation was conducted as an executive agreement by the Bush and Obama Administrations, not requiring congressional approval unless necessary. The ACTA negotiation was conducted as an executive agreement by the Bush and Obama Administrations, not requiring congressional approval unless necessary. The USTR states that the ACTA is consistent with existing U.S. law and does not require changes to U.S. law for implementation. The USTR maintains that ACTA does not need implementing legislation from Congress and can be carried out under existing legal authority. The United States may implement the ACTA without new legislation from Congress, as it aligns with existing legal authority. The congressional role in the ACTA is rooted in the U.S. Constitution, which grants Congress the power to regulate foreign commerce and intellectual property rights. The ACTA aligns with existing legal authority in the U.S. Congress has oversight and consultative roles in the negotiation and implementation of the ACTA, although it has not established a consultative role for itself in statute. The use of an executive agreement for the ACTA negotiations may be seen as a departure from past approaches to international trade negotiations on intellectual property rights. The United States has traditionally pursued IPR goals in international trade agreements subject to congressional approval. Concerns about global IPR infringement imposing costs on U.S. firms and consumers are high due to low risks and high profit margins associated with piracy. Technologies like digital media have increased piracy, while growing Internet usage has led to the distribution of counterfeit products in some countries. The increase in piracy, fueled by easily duplicated products like digital media and growing Internet usage, has led to the distribution of counterfeit goods. Inadequate penalties in some countries fail to deter counterfeiting and piracy. The protection of intellectual property rights (IPR) is crucial for the U.S. economy, with negative consequences for commercial, health, safety, and security. The U.S. participates in ACTA negotiations to address the economic impact of counterfeiting and piracy on its economy. The United States participates in ACTA negotiations to address the economic impact of counterfeiting and piracy on its economy, citing the economic importance of intellectual property rights (IPR) and the adverse effects on innovation and competitiveness. Advocates claim that counterfeiting and piracy result in significant revenue and trade losses for legitimate IPR-based industries, although quantifying these losses is challenging. The United States and other ACTA participants claim substantial economic losses from counterfeit and pirated goods, but quantifying these is difficult due to the secretive nature of IPR infringement. Digital media infringement is even harder to track, complicating data collection. Companies may withhold information on IPR infringement to protect their brand image. Some question the commercial rationale for ACTA. Some question the commercial rationale for the ACTA, as estimates for losses from IPR infringement may be biased. Critics argue that sales of pirated goods do not always result in direct revenue losses for legitimate firms, as some consumers may not purchase the legitimate version at market price. Advocates of civil liberties believe that government discussions on ACTA should consider the economic benefits of exceptions like "fair use" in copyright law. Some advocates argue that government discussions on ACTA should consider economic benefits of exceptions like "fair use" in copyright law. Critics believe IPR protection may favor private rights over broader economic and social welfare. U.S. participation in ACTA negotiations is also driven by health and safety concerns related to counterfeit products. The ACTA negotiation focuses on health and safety concerns related to counterfeit products, such as fake medicines and auto parts. There is debate over the conflation of counterfeiting with health threats, as legitimate products can still pose risks if substandard. Increasing IPR protection may impact access to affordable medicines. Some express concern that increasing IPR protection may pose challenges for public health, such as access to affordable medicines. U.S. involvement in the ACTA also centers on security concerns, with links between copyright piracy and organized crime syndicates. Arguments exist regarding the extent of this problem. The United States pursues IPR objectives through various trade policy mechanisms, including multilaterally through the WTO, regionally and bilaterally through FTAs, and domestically through U.S. trade laws. The ACTA aims to enhance the TRIPS Agreement by addressing gaps in international rules on IPR protection and enforcement. The United States supports the ACTA to address gaps in the TRIPS Agreement for IPR challenges, especially related to new technologies and piracy in digital media. Debates continue on the balance of rights and obligations in the TRIPS Agreement. The United States pursues international IPR protection through regional and bilateral FTAs, seeking levels of protection that exceed the TRIPS Agreement. Some IPR provisions in U.S. FTAs with Peru, Panama, and Colombia were revised following the Bipartisan Trade Agreement in 2007. U.S. FTAs have influenced the ACTA, sparking debates on the balance of rights and obligations in the IPR regime. Some IPR provisions in U.S. FTAs with Peru, Panama, and Colombia were revised, particularly for pharmaceutical-related IPR provisions. U.S. FTAs have influenced the ACTA, aiming to expand stronger IPR commitments to more countries. The ACTA seeks to model IPR enforcement provisions on agreements with Australia, Morocco, Singapore, and South Korea, including criminal penalties, border measures, and civil remedies for intellectual property rights. The ACTA is a plurilateral agreement focused on intellectual property rights (IPR) and aims to expand stronger IPR commitments to more countries. It differs from U.S. regional and bilateral FTAs by focusing solely on IPR. The negotiation process has sparked debates on transparency and inclusiveness among various stakeholder groups. Members of the U.S. business community, such as entertainment, pharmaceutical, and luxury goods industries, have expressed concerns about the ACTA negotiation. Certain stakeholders have concerns about the scope, transparency, and inclusiveness of the ACTA negotiation. U.S. business groups support the agreement for stronger international IPR protection, while others, like Internet service providers, have reservations about digital enforcement provisions. Civil society groups, such as public health advocates, worry about trade implications, consumer privacy, and information flow. Some question the rationale given existing international agreements on IPR. Public health and consumer rights advocates have raised concerns about the implications of the ACTA for trade in legitimate goods, consumer privacy, and free flow of information. Some question the need for a new agreement to combat counterfeiting and piracy when there are existing international agreements on IPR. The ACTA focuses on combating counterfeit goods, particularly trademark infringement of physical goods like fake medicines, toys, and auto parts. The ACTA negotiations broadened the scope of intellectual property rights to include piracy, in addition to traditional counterfeiting concerns. The European Union pushed for the inclusion of patents in civil enforcement, arguing it was necessary for industries like automotive, machinery, pharmaceuticals, and agro-chemicals. The European Union advocated for including patents in the civil enforcement section of the ACTA, arguing it was crucial for industries like automotive, machinery, pharmaceuticals, and agro-chemicals. The United States opposed this inclusion, with speculation that it conflicted with U.S. patent law. The final ACTA text allows parties to exclude patents from civil enforcement, with the U.S. stating it will do so. The United States and the EU had differing positions on including patents and trademarks in the ACTA. The EU supported including trademarks in digital enforcement due to concerns about infringement, while the US opposed it, possibly due to conflicting laws like the DMCA. The inclusion of trademarks in the digital enforcement section of the final ACTA text was a point of contention between the United States and the EU. While the EU supported it due to concerns about infringement, the US opposed it, citing potential conflicts with laws like the DMCA. The final text primarily focuses on copyright infringement over digital networks but does allow for disclosure of information to identify subscribers involved in trademark or copyright infringement. The ACTA negotiation process has raised concerns about transparency. The ACTA negotiation process has raised concerns about transparency, with critics noting a lack of public input and extensive consultations with consumer and public interest groups. Observers highlight the unprecedented level of secrecy in the negotiations compared to other international trade treaties. The ACTA negotiations have been criticized for their lack of transparency, with calls for increased public involvement. USTR has been urged to release draft texts for review and comment by Senators Sanders and Brown. Despite concerns, U.S. Trade Representative Kirk has defended the secrecy of the negotiations. The ACTA negotiation process was criticized for lack of transparency, with U.S. Trade Representative Kirk defending the secrecy citing security reasons. Draft texts were shared with cleared advisors and selected groups under non-disclosure agreements. The process became more transparent as negotiations progressed, with a summary of key elements released in November. The ACTA negotiation process initially lacked transparency, with industry and public interest groups required to sign non-disclosure agreements to view the negotiating text. However, transparency increased as negotiations advanced, with key elements summaries released in November 2009, a draft text in April 2010, and a finalized text in May 2011. USTR took steps to increase transparency, such as establishing a dedicated ACTA web page and releasing public agendas before each negotiating round. USTR increased transparency during the ACTA negotiation process by establishing a dedicated web page, releasing public summaries of issues, and consulting with Congress and stakeholders. During the ACTA negotiation process, USTR consulted with various stakeholders, including right holders, Internet intermediaries, and non-government organizations. The absence of developing country participation in the plurilateral agreement was a point of controversy. Some groups criticize the ACTA for being negotiated primarily among advanced industrialized countries, neglecting the interests of developing countries. China and India have expressed concerns that the ACTA could weaken rights and flexibilities negotiated in WTO agreements, create trade barriers, limit access to generic medicines, and restrict government's freedom in allocating resources for intellectual property rights enforcement. Other developing countries share similar views. The ACTA has sparked debate over the selection of participating countries, with some questioning why countries with inadequate IPR protection are involved. The 2012 Special 301 Report included Canada, Mexico, Finland, and Romania on watch lists. Participation in the ACTA is seen as a way for these countries to enhance IPR enforcement, but concerns remain about the effectiveness of the agreement without countries like China and Russia involved. According to the USTR, participation in the ACTA may help countries in the Special 301 report enhance IPR enforcement. Some question the effectiveness without China and Russia. The agreement may expand to include more countries after the signatory period. USTR hopes for more countries to join over time. The ACTA Committee oversees the agreement and accession of new members. USTR hopes for more countries to join over time, reflecting the growing international consensus on the need for strong IPR enforcement. Critics speculate that developing countries may be pressured to adhere to the ACTA to obtain trade benefits. The negotiation has sparked debate on the impact of increasing IPR protection on legitimate trade and consumer activities. The ACTA negotiation has sparked debate about the impact of increasing IPR protection on trade and consumer activities. IPR-based industries support the ACTA for economic growth, while some groups fear it may interfere with trade in legitimate goods. Negotiating parties maintain that the ACTA respects public health and civil liberties, with safeguards against barriers to trade. The ACTA negotiation has sparked debate about its impact on trade and consumer activities. It is stated that the ACTA respects public health, civil liberties, and contains safeguards against barriers to trade. The USTR released a statement confirming that ACTA will not interfere with fundamental rights and liberties, and will be consistent with the TRIPS Agreement. It was reiterated that ACTA will not hinder the cross-border transit of legitimate generic medicines or oblige border authorities to search travelers' baggage for infringing materials. The ACTA negotiation has sparked debate about its impact on trade and consumer activities. It is stated that the ACTA respects public health, civil liberties, and contains safeguards against barriers to trade. ACTA will not oblige border authorities to search travelers' baggage or personal electronic devices for infringing materials. Critics are concerned about the potential impact on consumer privacy and free flow of information, particularly regarding digital enforcement provisions that could lead to ISPs terminating customers' Internet accounts after repeated allegations of copyright infringement. Some members of Parliament view Internet access as a human right that should only be terminated by judges. There is a debate about increasing ISP involvement in enforcing intellectual property rights, with critics arguing that filtering communication places undue burdens on ISPs. Civil liberties groups are concerned about the low threshold for terminating Internet access, stating that proof of online piracy should be required. Legislation like the PROTECT IP Act and SOPA aim to address online piracy, sparking heightened debate about ISP obligations related to intellectual property infringement. The PROTECT IP Act and SOPA were introduced in the 112th Congress to address online piracy, similar to ACTA. Concerns were raised about maintaining U.S. "fair use" practices and potential implications for the free flow of information. The final ACTA text does not include a "three-strikes" rule. The final ACTA text does not include a "three-strikes" rule or "notice-and-takedown" rules. Instead, it requires competent authorities to order ISPs to disclose information to identify subscribers involved in infringement, while also ensuring that digital enforcement procedures do not create barriers to legitimate activities. The ACTA aims to avoid creating barriers to legitimate activity and preserve fundamental principles like freedom of expression and privacy. Border enforcement provisions allow customs officials to seize goods suspected of infringing IPR, with some countries granting ex-officio authority in limited cases. In the United States, CBP can seize goods violating copyrights and trademarks but not patents. In the United States, U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) can seize goods violating copyrights and trademarks but not patents. Many business groups advocate for customs officials to have ex-officio authority to combat counterfeit goods more effectively. Critics argue that this could cause delays in the movement of goods. The ACTA negotiation included discussions on border enforcement measures to combat trademark counterfeiting and copyright piracy. Critics raised concerns about potential delays in trade, increased costs, and impediments to personal travel. There were debates on including patents in the enforcement section, with worries about undermining legitimate trade in generic medicines and public health. Some public health advocates feared customs authorities making determinations on patent violations could hinder exports and imports of legitimate generic drugs. The ACTA negotiation included discussions on border enforcement measures to combat trademark counterfeiting and copyright piracy. Critics raised concerns about potential delays in trade, increased costs, and impediments to personal travel. Some groups contended that empowering customs authorities to make determinations about patent violations could hinder exports and imports of legitimate generic drugs. The border enforcement section of the ACTA specifically excludes patents and focuses on other forms of intellectual property rights like trademarks and copyrights, raising concerns about access to generic medicines. The ACTA was negotiated separately from existing multilateral institutions like the WTO and WIPO, sparking debate. Advocates argue that this approach allowed for more efficient global IPR protection. Multilateral trade negotiations have stalled, with the WTO Doha Round at a standstill over country differences. The advancement of trade negotiations in multilateral venues has stalled in recent years, with the WTO Doha Round at a standstill over country differences. WIPO members have not reached an agreement on new elements for discussion on the global patent agenda. ACTA negotiating parties believe the agreement is innovative and not fitting under current multilateral frameworks. Critics argue that holding negotiations outside existing frameworks was controversial. Some critics argue that the ACTA negotiations were held outside existing multilateral frameworks to bypass concerns of developing countries. There are questions about the ACTA's long-term status and whether it will be incorporated into the WTO. Negotiating parties hope the WTO will adopt ACTA standards in the future, with Japanese officials aiming to make ACTA a model for international rules within the WTO framework. Some speculate that if the ACTA becomes part of the WTO, signing on to the ACTA could become a requirement for WTO accession. Supporters argue that the ACTA enhances IPR protection and enforcement, filling gaps in current frameworks, especially in the digital environment. The ACTA aims to address gaps in current legal frameworks and enforcement practices for IPR infringement, particularly in the digital environment. Critics argue that it may overlap with existing treaties like the WIPO Internet treaties and the WTO TRIPS Agreement. The United States has been seen as a key supporter of IPR, but critics question the need for the ACTA, suggesting it may duplicate existing international agreements. Some argue that current mechanisms for addressing IPR issues are underutilized, while others question the effectiveness of new trade agreements without stronger legal protections. Enforcement of existing IPR laws is seen as a key issue that the ACTA aims to address. The ACTA is seen as potentially addressing gaps in the enforcement of existing IPR laws globally, with the potential to impact countries like Canada in enforcing IPR in the digital environment. The 112th Congress may consider its role in the ACTA approval process and whether implementation without congressional approval could raise constitutional issues. The 112th Congress may examine the role of Congress in the ACTA approval process, considering potential constitutional issues. Questions include Congress's role, potential impact on congressional action, and prioritization of intellectual property rights enforcement. The proposed ACTA raises questions about congressional action, prioritization of IPR enforcement, allocation of federal funds, and implications for U.S. trade policy. Key concerns include commercial losses, health and safety risks from counterfeit products, and setting a precedent for future IPR protection efforts. The implementation of the ACTA raises questions about the appropriation of federal funds and its implications for U.S. trade policy, future IPR protection efforts, and negotiating objectives. It also raises concerns about whether accession to the ACTA would be required for future U.S. regional and bilateral FTAs, and how it would affect USTR determinations for its Special 301 watch lists. Additionally, the prospects for the ACTA entering into force are uncertain following the European Parliament's rejection.
